scenario:
Public Storage (PSA) saw its share price more than double between 2020 and 2022 due to a pandemic-aided boom in the self-storage industry. However, the stock has dropped roughly 30% from its highs since then. Despite this, the company's sales have grown by 12% over the last two years. Public Storage's cash generation has not kept pace with its impressive financial results, leaving the market dismayed.

The company's leadership advantage, vast scale, and best-in-class operations make it a top-tier investment. Public Storage holds the highest Moody's and S&P Global credit ratings of any U.S. REIT, securing funding at attractive rates and allowing it to add 36% more square feet of storage space to its portfolio through $11.7 billion of investments. The company's digital operating model, implemented early in the self-storage industry, offers digital access, a digital care team, and kiosks, giving it an advantage in acquiring new customers.

Public Storage generates 75% of its new customers through its digital eRental program, compared to its peers' average of 30%. The company's cash-generating capabilities remain superior compared to its self-storage peers, with higher free cash flows (FCF) and a higher cash return on invested capital (ROIC).

The company's high return on invested capital in a fragmented market, combined with its ability to generate outsized cash flows from new investments, makes it a prime candidate for continued consolidation through mergers and acquisitions (M&A). Public Storage's investments should pay dividends once the cyclical industry returns to sunnier days.

The company offers a higher-than-average 4.1% dividend yield, which is about 20% above its 10-year average. Public Storage's valuation is near a decade-long low, trading at 17 times cash from operations (CFO), making it a discounted valuation. The company's best-in-class operations, enticing growth prospects, and discounted valuation make it one of the author's favorite S&P 500 dividend stocks to buy in 2025 and hold forever.
